section.para: The {annotation} element represents an annotation that an author, editor, publisher, republisher, or other individual or agency has added to a document.
The {[[#z3986.ref.attrib]]} attribute identifies the specific element(s) being annotated by referencing their {xml:id} values.
All {annotation} elements must reference at least one element in a document. For annotations that apply to more than one element, use a space-separated list of {xml:id} values.

The {caption} element represents a short explanation or description accompanying a component of a publication. Captions most often occur in conjunction with illustrations, photographs, tables and diagrams.
The {[[#z3986.ref.attrib]]} attribute identifies the component(s) to which the caption applies.

The {code} element is intended for general instances of code as found in works of fiction and similar non-technical documents, which includes computer programming code, commands and command input/output as well as representations of numeric and text coding systems, such as Morse code.
For computer programming books, manuals and specifications, specializing the {code} element or using a computer markup feature is recommended.
The {item} element represents a single item in a list.
The {list} element represents a simple list of items, either ordered or unordered.
The optional {type} attribute specifies the HTML-style ordered and unordered nature of the list. If omitted, the value {unordered} is assumed.
By default, an unordered list is prefixed by bullets and an ordered list by numeric values. To change this behavior, refer to the {rend:prefix} attribute.
The {list} element is not intended to structure semantically meaningful set of entries as found in indexes, bibliographies and glossaries.
The {object} element contains a reference to an external resource, such a a graphic or video.
The formal behavior of the {object} element is defined by {[[http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11 XHTML 1.1]]}.
The {quote} element represents a quotation from a real or fictitious source.

The {[[#z3986.role.attrib]]} attribute optionally expresses the semantic nature of the quote. For example, adding the value 'epigraph' would indicate the quote represents an epigraph for the document or section it belongs to.
The {verse} element represents a non-prose passage such as a poem, song, hymn etc., with or without metrical structure.
